qas.question: How did William Shirley feel about English advancement?

context: In his extensively detailed report, Céloron wrote, "All I can say is that the Natives of these localities <a0_2>are <a0_0><a0_1><a0_4><b3_0><b4_0>very badly disposed towards the French<a0_4/><a0_1/>, and are entirely devoted to the English<b4_0/><b3_0/><a0_2/><a0_0/>. I don't know in <a0_3>what way they could be brought back<a0_3/>." Even before his return to Montreal, reports on the situation in the Ohio Country were making their way to London and Paris, <a1_1><a1_3>each side <a1_0><a1_2><b5_0><b6_0>proposing that action be taken<b6_0/><b5_0/><a1_3/><a1_2/><a1_1/><a1_0/>. William Shirley, the expansionist governor of the Province of Massachusetts Bay, was particularly <a2_4>forceful<a2_4/>, stating that <a2_0><a2_1><a2_2><a2_3><b7_0>British colonists would not be safe<a2_3/><a2_1/> as long as the French were present<b7_0/><a2_2/><a2_0/>. Conflicts between the colonies, accomplished through raiding parties that included Indian allies, had taken place for decades, leading to a brisk trade in European colonial captives from either side.
